video_caption: The video begins with a solid yellow background, transitioning to a title card that reads "COMPUTER TUTORIAL How To Speed Up Windows 10 Performance" in bold, colorful letters against a yellow backdrop. The scene then shifts to a Windows 10 desktop screen, showcasing the default blue wallpaper with the Windows logo. Various icons, including "The PC," "Play File," "Google Chrome," "SHAREit," "Microsoft Edge," "OneDrive," and "RAMMAP 3.95," are visible on the left side of the screen. The taskbar at the bottom displays the time as 10:38 and the date as 11/06/2017, along with several application icons. A cursor moves across the screen, and a text overlay appears, stating "01 Power Option" in a speech bubble, indicating the first step in the tutorial. The video maintains a consistent focus on the desktop environment, emphasizing the instructional content related to optimizing Windows 10 performance.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop screen, showcasing the default blue wallpaper with the Windows logo. The taskbar at the bottom displays several icons, including Google Chrome, File Explorer, and Microsoft Edge. The Start menu is open, revealing various applications and settings, such as Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, and File Explorer. The date and time are visible in the bottom right corner, showing "10/06/2017" and "10:39 AM." The cursor moves to the search bar, types "power," and selects "Power Options" from the search results. The Power Options window opens, displaying different power plans and settings. The cursor adjusts the screen brightness slider and then closes the Power Options window. The desktop screen returns to its original state, with the Start menu closed and the taskbar icons visible. The video concludes with the desktop screen remaining static, showing the default wallpaper and taskbar icons.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with the Windows logo. Several icons are visible on the desktop, including "This PC," "Recycle Bin," "Google Chrome," "Games," "Snip & Sketch," "OneNote," and "Daisy." The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 10:39 and the date as 13/09/2017. The cursor moves to the right side of the screen, clicks on the Start button, and opens the Start menu. The cursor then selects "View" from the menu, revealing options such as "Toolbars," "Show Task View button," and "Show Windows Ink Workspace button." The cursor hovers over "Toolbars" and opens a submenu with options like "Cortana," "Show Task View button," and "Show Windows Ink Workspace button." The cursor then moves to the search bar at the bottom of the screen and types "Task Manager." The Task Manager window opens, displaying a list of startup applications with their status, publisher, and startup impact. The cursor highlights "Microsoft OneDrive" and right-clicks to reveal options such as "Open file location," "Disable," and "Enable." The cursor selects "Disable," and the status of "Microsoft OneDrive" changes to "Disabled." The video concludes with the Task Manager window still open, showing the updated list of startup applications. Throughout the video, the Windows 10 desktop background remains consistent, and the time and date on the taskbar do not change.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a glowing window design. Several icons are visible on the left side of the screen, including 'The PC,' 'Pyrofile,' 'Google Chrome,' 'SHAREit,' 'Superhuman Folders,' and 'OneDrive.' A notification banner at the bottom reads '03 Defragment' with a yellow speech bubble and a pink thumbs-up icon. The Windows Start menu is then opened, displaying various applications such as 'Google Chrome,' 'Microsoft Edge,' 'File Explorer,' 'Skype,' 'Twitter,' 'Minecraft,' and 'OneNote.' The user types 'defrag' into the search bar, leading to a list of search results, with 'Defragment and Optimize Drives' highlighted. The user clicks on this option, opening the 'Optimize Drives' window, which shows the status of drives C: and E: as 'OK (0% Fragmented).' The user clicks the 'Analyze' button, and the status of drive C: changes to '0% Fragmented.' The user then clicks the 'Optimize' button, and the status of drive C: changes to '0% Fragmented.' The video concludes with the 'Optimize Drives' window still open, showing the status of the drives and the scheduled optimization settings.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a light effect resembling a window. The desktop is populated with various icons, including folders and applications such as 'The PC,' 'Pygame,' 'Google Chrome,' 'Steam,' 'SHAREit,' 'Microsoft Edge,' 'OneDrive,' and 'RAMSH 3977 ATS.' The taskbar at the bottom displays the time as 11:39 and the date as 13/08/2017. The cursor moves to the 'This PC' icon, right-clicks, and selects 'Manage,' opening the 'Computer Management' window. The 'Disk Management' section is highlighted, showing the 'Local Disk (C:)' with details about its type, used space, free space, and capacity. The cursor then clicks on the 'Disk Cleanup' option, opening a new window that lists files to be deleted, such as 'Temporary Internet Files,' 'System Restore and Shadow Copies,' and 'Windows Update Cleanup.' The user proceeds to select all files and clicks 'OK,' initiating the cleanup process. The 'Disk Cleanup' window shows the progress of the cleanup, indicating that the process is ongoing. The video concludes with the 'Disk Cleanup' window still open, showing the progress of the cleanup process, while the 'Computer Management' window remains visible in the background.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a light window design. Several icons are visible on the desktop, including "The PC," "File Explorer," "Google Chrome," "SHAREit," "Snip & Sketch," "Microsoft Forms," and "Daisy." The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 1:31 PM and the date as 10/06/2017. A text overlay in the bottom left corner reads "05 Visual Settings" with a yellow circle and a blue speech bubble. The user then opens the Start menu by clicking the Windows icon, revealing options such as "System Information," "System Configuration," "Clean Sys Vol Folder," and "Settings." The user types "sy" into the search bar, and the search results update to show "System Information," "System Configuration," "Settings," "System," "Check for updates," "Windows Update," "Reset this PC," "About your PC," "Taskbar notification area," and "System." The user selects "System" from the search results, opening the "System" window, which displays information about the computer, including the processor, RAM, and display. The user then opens the "System Properties" window, showing details such as the computer name, processor, and memory. The user navigates to the "Advanced" tab and clicks on "Settings" under "Performance," opening the "Performance Options" window. The user selects "Adjust for best performance" and clicks "Apply" and "OK" to save the changes. The video concludes with the "Performance Options" window still open, showing the selected settings.

The video showcases a static view of a Windows 10 desktop screen, featuring a blue background with a light window design. On the left side of the screen, there are several icons, including "The PC," "File Re," "Google Chrome," "GAMES," "Microsoft Forms," and "OneDrive." The taskbar at the bottom displays the Windows Start button, search bar, and several pinned applications such as File Explorer, Microsoft Edge, and Google Chrome. The system tray on the right side shows the time as 11:43 AM and the date as 15/08/2017. The desktop remains unchanged throughout the video, with no visible actions or movements.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a glowing window design. Several icons are visible, including 'The PC,' 'File Explorer,' 'Google Chrome,' 'Games,' 'Networkshare Folders,' and 'OneDrive.' The taskbar shows the time as 13:14 and the date as 11/06/2017. The cursor moves to the 'File Explorer' icon, opens it, and navigates to the 'Run' command in the search bar, typing '%temp%' to open the temporary files folder. The cursor then selects all files in the 'Temp' folder and attempts to delete them, but a pop-up message indicates that the folder cannot be deleted because it is in use by another program. The video concludes with the cursor still on the 'Try Again' button in the pop-up message.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a glowing window design. Several icons are visible on the desktop, including "The PC," "File Reo," "Google Chrome," "SHARE," "Merchandise Folders," and "Dass." The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 11:32 and the date as 10/06/2017. The cursor moves to the search bar, types "run," and opens the Run dialog box. The user types "temp" into the Run dialog box and presses Enter, opening the Temp folder. The Temp folder contains various files and folders, with the cursor highlighting the "Temp" folder. The user then deletes the contents of the Temp folder, leaving it empty. The scene transitions to the user opening the Run dialog box again, this time typing "prefetch" and pressing Enter, opening the Prefetch folder. The Prefetch folder contains numerous files, and the user selects all files using the "Ctrl+A" shortcut. The video concludes with the user right-clicking on the selected files, opening a context menu with options such as "Add to 'Temp' and email," "Compress to 'Temp.zip' and email," "Copy," "Create shortcut," "Delete," and "Properties." The cursor hovers over the "Delete" option, indicating the user's intention to delete the selected files.

The video begins with a view of a Windows desktop featuring a blue background with a Windows logo. The desktop is populated with several icons, including 'This PC,' 'File Explorer,' 'Google Chrome,' and 'SHAREit.' The taskbar at the bottom displays the time as 11:38 and the date as 10/20/2017. The cursor moves to the 'File Explorer' icon, opening a window that reveals folders such as 'Quick access,' 'Desktop,' 'Downloads,' and 'Documents.' The cursor then navigates to the 'Run' option in the Start menu, opening a dialog box where 'msconfig' is typed into the 'Open' field. The 'OK' button is clicked, leading to the 'System Configuration' window, which displays a list of services. The cursor selects 'Hide all Microsoft services,' and a 'SUBSCRIBE FOR MORE VIDEOS' banner appears in red at the top right corner of the screen. The video concludes with the 'System Configuration' window still open, showing the updated list of services with Microsoft services hidden.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a glowing window design. Several icons are visible on the left side, including "The PC," "Play Reo," "Google Chrome," "SHAREit," "RemoShore Folders," and "DOS." A text overlay at the bottom reads "08 Regedit," accompanied by a yellow circle and a pink arrow pointing to the right. The Windows TV logo is displayed in the top right corner. The scene transitions to the Windows Start menu, showcasing various applications such as Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Skype, Twitter, and OneNote. The user then opens the search bar and types "regedit," leading to the Run dialog box where "regedit" is typed into the search field. The user clicks "OK," and the Regedit application opens, displaying the Windows Registry Editor interface. The video concludes with the Regedit window open, showing the Windows Registry Editor interface with a list of registry keys and values.

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a light effect resembling a window. The desktop is adorned with several icons, including 'This PC,' 'Recycle Bin,' 'Google Chrome,' and 'SHAREit.' The taskbar at the bottom displays the Start button, search bar, and pinned applications such as File Explorer, Microsoft Edge, and Google Chrome. The system tray shows the time as 11:37 and the date as 15/06/2017. The user opens the 'Run' dialog box, types 'regedit,' and presses Enter, launching the Registry Editor. The Registry Editor window appears, displaying a hierarchical list of registry keys on the left and a detailed view of the selected key on the right. The user navigates through the registry, expanding the 'Computer' key to reveal subkeys like 'HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT,' 'HKEY_CURRENT_USER,' and 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE.' The user then selects 'HKEY_CURRENT_USER' and further navigates to 'Control Panel\Mouse,' where various mouse settings are listed. The user opens the 'Mouse' settings, revealing options such as 'DoubleClickSpeed,' 'MouseSensitivity,' and 'MouseThreshold1.' The user adjusts the 'MouseSensitivity' value to 10 and saves the changes. The video concludes with the user navigating back to the 'Control Panel' and selecting 'Display,' where display settings are listed, including 'Screen Resolution' and 'Display Adapter Properties.' The user opens the 'Display' settings, revealing options such as 'Screen Resolution,' 'Display Adapter Properties,' and 'Wallpaper.' The video ends with the user navigating back to the 'Control Panel' and selecting 'Display,' where display settings are listed, including 'Screen Resolution' and 'Display Adapter Properties.' The user opens the 'Display' settings, revealing options such as 'Screen Resolution,' 'Display Adapter Properties,' and 'Wallpaper.' The video ends with the user navigating back to the 'Control Panel' and selecting 'Display,' where display settings are listed, including 'Screen Resolution' and 'Display Adapter Properties.' The user opens the 'Display' settings, revealing options such as 'Screen Resolution,' 'Display Adapter Properties,' and 'Wallpaper.' The video ends with the user navigating back to the 'Control Panel' and selecting 'Display,' where display settings are listed, including 'Screen Resolution' and 'Display Adapter Properties.' The user opens the 'Display' settings, revealing options

The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop screen, featuring a blue background with the Windows logo. Several icons are visible on the left side of the screen, including "The PC," "File Re," "Google Chrome," "SHARE," "NVIDIA GeForce," "Oasis," and "RAMSHY 3977 ATS." The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 11:38 and the date as 13/08/2017. A right-click context menu is open, displaying options such as "Graphics Properties," "View," "Sort by," "Paste shortcut," "Paste," "Graphics Properties," "Graphics Options," "New," "Display settings," and "Refresh." The mouse cursor is positioned over the "Graphics Properties" option. The scene then transitions to a green background with a white rectangle in the center, containing the text "Easy Classes" at the top, followed by "Thank You" in large letters, "Like & Share" in blue, and "SUBSCRIBE" in red with a green outline. Below this, the text "FOR MORE VIDEOS" is displayed in black. The video concludes with this message, encouraging viewers to like, share, and subscribe for more content.
